awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Functional Fabric Devices and Architectures for the Internet of Things
awd_abstract_narration:
Functional fabrics are textiles designed to perform a wide variety of functions with applications ranging from medicine and sports to realizing the potential of textile-based smart devices (e.g., clothing, drapes, upholstery) as sensor networks within the Internet of Things (IoT). One particularly compelling application of functional fabrics is in the area of wearables for the IoT, which are becoming ubiquitous. Coupled with pervasive access to smart phones and wireless Internet, they are enabling exciting new application domains, notably in smart homes and wearable health systems. The next generation of wearables for the Internet of Things are likely to be fully integrated into textiles, turning the fabric into garment and textile devices.  The applications that functional fabrics will enable, leveraging the networking technologies that will be developed in this proposal, will vary widely between what will one day be seen as: mundane (e.g., smart drapes with sensors that measure and regulate temperature within a room), convenient (e.g., smart laundry that will help prevent bright colored clothing from being washed with whites), personal / professional productivity (e.g., convergence of functional fabrics with voice and data transceivers for social / work applications), as well as life-changing/saving (e.g., biomedical functional fabrics with textile based sensors and soft robotic actuators for collecting data, enabling seamless telemedicine, and remote actuated treatments). 

The use of passive radio frequency identification (RFID), in particular, is an enabling technology for high density deployments since each functional fabric device would not require a battery or cumbersome transceiver electronics. We will use a balanced approach between theory and implementation, to develop architectures for passive RFID-based functional fabrics and associated sensor solutions. The density of functional fabrics will be much larger than conventional RFID networks, requiring a coordinated network of cognitive RFID interrogators that use spatial and spectral degrees of freedom to isolate individual devices. Passive RFID sensor devices provide pseudo-periodic connectivity with IoT services and provide the ability to sample and report the physical surroundings independently from supporting infrastructure. Message concentration protocols for this supporting infrastructure will be considered. Enabling these networks will require challenging assumptions that have been made regarding physical layer (PHY) and medium access control (MAC) layer design for RFID architectures, and we will leverage a combination of network modeling along with prototyping on a flexible software defined radio (SDR) to propose new IoT architectures and protocols.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project advanced the development and application of passive RFID systems, functional fabrics, and wearable IoT sensors, addressing critical challenges in non-traditional material IoT devices, energy efficiency, high-density deployments, and real-time data processing. The outcomes have significant implications for healthcare, industrial IoT, and consumer technologies, with notable contributions to education and commercialization.

Intellectual Merit

Key outcomes of this project include:

Energy-Efficient Wearable Monitoring: A wireless, non-invasive wearable system called the Bellypatch was developed for monitoring respiratory rates. Using a convolutional neural network (CNN), the system achieved 97.15% classification accuracy. A spiking neural network (SNN) further reduced energy consumption by 18x, enabling long-term use in resource-constrained medical settings.

Passive RFID Indoor Localization:  A machine learning-based localization system was created using a reconfigurable RFID reader antenna. This system achieved high accuracy, with 90% of RFID tags localized within 1 meter, demonstrating potential for applications like inventory tracking and contact tracing.

Nanomaterial Advances for IoT:  Research on Ti3C2Tx MXene nanomaterials revealed exceptional radio frequency (RF) conductivity, exceeding their DC conductivity. These findings provide guidelines for designing next-generation IoT devices using flexible materials.

Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces:  A laboratory scale prototype and embedded controllers for dynamically reconfigurable intelligent surfaces were developed. These systems support applications like high density IoT deployment and adaptive wireless communications and networking.

Biomedical Monitoring with Functional Fabrics:  Stretchable fabric antennas and commercial RFID were integrated into garments and other medical devices for unobtrusive monitoring of respiration and other biomedical signals. Enhanced algorithms improved signal processing efficiency and accuracy, opening possibilities for wearable health monitoring devices..

 

Broader Impacts

This project has significant societal and educational impacts:

Medical IoT Innovations: Low-cost, passive IoT devices were created for healthcare, including diaper moisture sensors and intravenous fluid level monitors. These solutions are battery-free, lightweight, and reliable, addressing the needs of infants, elderly patients, and their caregivers.

Technology Commercialization: The project included invention disclosures and patent applications submitted in the area of functional fabrics and reconfigurable intelligent surfaces.  Working with our Drexel Applied Innovation office, we are seeking commercailization partners for the developed technologies, and have had promising discussions with several potential industrial partners..

Undergraduate Research: The project actively engaged female and underrepresented minority students through the Vertically Integrated Projects (VIP) and senior design program at Drexel University, contributing to diversity and inclusion in engineering and technology fields.

Conclusion 

This project has made substantial contributions to IoT and RFID technologies, particularly in wearable health monitoring and the use of non-traditional material devices for IoT. It also emphasized educational outreach and partnership with industry, ensuring broad societal and technological benefits. These advancements lay the foundation for future research and real-world applications in IoT, healthcare, and functional fabrics.
